They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a married woman who lives in Danao City, Cebu. She operates 2 business ventures: a general store and a food vending (bananaque) business. Her husband, Marcelo, who is 52 years old, works as a carpenter and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children aged between 18 and 23 years old. 

Flora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Flora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,600, lifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000. She intends to use this to buy more products to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and house repairs. Flora is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase additional product items to sell

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is a married woman with six children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Mwanaisha has operated a boda boda (motorcycle transport) business for the past two years. Her local neighbours are potential customers. Her major challenge is seasonality. She hopes to purchase a matatu (van/small bus) in the future.

With the Kshs 60,000, she wants to purchase a motorcycle for her transport business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her transport business.

loans.name: Eric Opanga

texts.en:
Eric Opanga is a sole proprietor businessman who runs a spare-parts shop in the Kosirai Trading Centre in Kapsabet town. He has been in this business for seven years, and earns an income of 8,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month.  He is 23 years old and married with one child who is 7 months old; he supports three people.  

He has never borrowed from any other MFI (microfinance institution), and he learned about KADET from a member of a group registered with KADET. He is applying for a first loan from KADET LTD, with which he plans to buy more stock of spare parts for sale.          

Eric intends to use the anticipated profit to save and plow back into the business. In the future, he desires to grow his business, buy a plot of land and settle his family.

loans.use: Purchase stock of spare parts

loans.name: Ramula

texts.en: Ramula G. is a widow with seven adult children. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.  For the past five years, she has operated a food stall selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Ramula faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During dry hot season, the demand for products is high compared to rainy cold season where demand is low. She dreams of expanding her business and selling wholesale.  Ramula is requesting a loan for 25,000 KES, which she will use to buy sugar, coffee, and fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase one  sugar, coffee and fish

loans.name: Apec Al Ouma Ngor Groupe 2

texts.fr:
Apec Al Ouma groupe 2 regroupe 12 femmes qui vivent toutes dans la localité de Ngor, un village environnant qui se situe entre Ouakam et Yoff. Elles évoluent toutes dans le domaine du commerce et elles ont des activités séparées de vente de produits divers tels que denrées alimentaires, produits locaux, tissus, habits, friperie, produits de beauté et petite restauration. Elles  sont représentées par madame Khardiata S.. Elle voyage fréquemment pour aller a Diaobe un marché hebdomadaire ou elle se procure des produits locaux comme la pâte de d’arachide, les poissons séchés, etc. Elle vend aussi des produits cosmétiques. Elle a choisi son activité de commerce par nécessité pour  subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Elle a une expérience d’une dizaine d’années environ dans son activité. Son objectif est de lutter contre le chômage     et  la pauvreté. Le sous groupe est membre du guichet de Ouakam depuis février 2011. Il sollicite un crédit de 2 075 000 dans le but de se procurer des produits à vendre pour chaque membre. Elles souhaitent renforcer leurs fonds de commerce, élargir et diversifier leurs activités respectives et faire face à la demande croissante de leurs clients.

Al Ouma is a Senegalese nonprofit whose full name is The Association for Koranic Education and Teaching. 
 
Originally founded to work with at-risk children, especially talibés (young boys from poor families who beg in Senegalese metropolitan areas), Al Ouma has evolved its mission to work with adults as well as children. They currently have over 10,000 members, and are actively engaged in supporting the economic development of their members in the hopes of improving their quality of life, and that of their at-risk children.
 
Al Ouma's members are currently organized into smaller associations which meet each week to contribute to a group fund that helps finance small loans for members.  Members typically put in $2 USD per week. Because UIMCEC and Al Ouma both share the mission of fighting poverty through economic empowerment, they have formed a partnership to provide loans to Al Ouma associations at a lower interest rate than UIMCEC usually offers its clients.
texts.en:
Apec Al Ouma group 2 unites 12 women who all live in Ngor, a neighboring village which is situated between Ouakam et Yoff. They are all working in commerce and they have separate activities selling various products such as foodstuffs, local products, cloth, clothes, used clothing, cosmetics and cooked foods. 

They are represented by Mrs. Khardiata S.. She frequently travels to Diaobe, a weekly market, where she buys local products such as peanut butter, dried fish, etc. She also sells cosmetics. She chose to do business as a matter of necessity, to support her family. She has been in this business for some 10 years. Her goal is to fight joblessness and poverty. 

This sub-group has been a member of the Ouakam office since February 2011. It is requesting a loan of 2,075,000 francs so each member can buy merchandise to resell. The members wish to bolster their working capital, expand and diversify their respective activities, and meet the growing demand of their customers.  

Al Ouma is a Senegalese nonprofit whose full name is The Association for Koranic Education and Teaching. 
 
Originally founded to work with at-risk children, especially talibés (young boys from poor families who beg in Senegalese metropolitan areas), Al Ouma has evolved its mission to work with adults as well as children. They currently have over 10,000 members, and are actively engaged in supporting the economic development of their members in the hopes of improving their quality of life, and that of their at-risk children.
 
Al Ouma's members are currently organized into smaller associations which meet each week to contribute to a group fund that helps finance small loans for members.  Members typically put in 2 USD per week. Because UIMCEC and Al Ouma both share the mission of fighting poverty through economic empowerment, they have formed a partnership to provide loans to Al Ouma associations at a lower interest rate than UIMCEC usually offers its clients.

loans.use: to buy local products and cosmetics, etc. for resale

loans.name: 50 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Cầu Lê Thị (3) is a 61 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Cầu is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 50 Quảng Hưng (18.6.50 Quảng Hưng). 

Cầu is widowed and has five adult children. To making a living, Cầu raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. Cầu has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) a month from these activities. 

In 2009, Cầu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Cầu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will also be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. This loan will be the fourth loan she has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cầu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 

1. H. Thị Hương (2) is a 31-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business. 

2. N. Thị Thanh (6) is a 53-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock raising business. 

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: 

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. 

Cầu Lê Thị (three) là 61 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Cầu là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có three các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 50 Quảng Hưng (18.6. 50 Quảng Hưng). 

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán. Cầu thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Cầu kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND. Vào 2009, Cầu đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/anh ấy. Cầu đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND. 

Khoản vay sẽ là fourth khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. 

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 

1. H. Thị Hương (two) là 31 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất. 

2. N. Thị Thanh (six) là 53 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: 

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. 

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch.. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.. "

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.es:
Anastacia,se dedica a la venta de comida, pupusas, tortillas, ella vive con su esposo y tres hijos, su negocio lo tiene en una vivienda alquilada, tiene aproximadamente tres años de estar en el negocio.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de maíz, quesillo y materiales para preparar los alimentos que vende, este préstamo le ayudara a mejorar la producción y dar un mejor servicio a los clientes.
Los objetivos de Anastasia son, mejorar el negocio, ayudar a sus hijos a estudiar y también invertir en la vivienda.
texts.en:
Anastacia lives in San Francisco Gotera, in the department of Morazán. She sells food like tortillas and pupusas--a traditional Salvadoran dish made of handmade corn flat bread stuffed with cheese, fried pork rind, and/or refried beans. She lives with her husband and three children. Her business is located downtown in a rented space. She has been in business for approximately 3 years. 
She is requesting a loan in order to purchase corn, quesillo--a type of soft cheese, and other ingredients to make the dishes she sells. This loan will help her increase production and provide better customer service. 
Anastasia's goals are to improve her business, to help her children get an education, and to invest in her home.

loans.use: to buy corn, cheese and condiments.

loans.name: Vat

texts.en:
The person shown in the picture is Vat, age 47.  He lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang. He is a building worker in and around his village. From his job, he typically makes around $1.75 income each day to manage his family's daily expenses. To help better meet the family's demands, his wife makes Khmer cakes to sell and earns approximately $1.25 a day.  This couple resides with their three children, two of whom are students and one has married and lives separately. 

Vat has decided to seek a loan from Kiva to purchase more ingredients to make Khmer cake for sale and to buy zinc to cover the roof of his house that has cracked.

loans.use: buy ingredients to make cakes to sell and to repair house roof

loans.name: Panar's Group

texts.en:
Panar is the leader of this group. She is 56 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she has raised a son. The son is 22 years old, he is engaged in farming.

In order to earn money to meet their daily needs the family breeds cattle. They resell cattle at the higher price after fattening them. Panar also makes additional money by selling dairy products. In this way she earns an additional 3000 soms per month. 

Panar applied for the loan because she needs additional funds for purchasing a calf. In the future Panar wants to improve the family's living conditions. She will be happy to see her son get married. 

---Where Did This Loan Come From?---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.Kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team-Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://Kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf

loans.name: Gayane

texts.en: Gayane is from the village of Akhouryan in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is a widow with three chidren – a twenty-three-year-old daughter and two sons (sixteen and twenty-six).  Gayane has a high school education and has been a sole entrepreneur engaged in farming for the past twenty-five years.  She considers herself a hard-working honest person.  Gayane would like a loan to purchase potato seeds and feed.  This investment should increase Gayane’s family income by ten percent.  With some of the proceeds from the investment Gayane will be saving some money to renovate the family home.  She is proud of living in Akhouryan and the ability to maintain her family.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and feed

loans.name: Janith

texts.en: Janith is 29 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. Janith has a shop that sells chickens like broilers. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy additional chickens to raise & sell in the future. Janith has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Janith hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional chickens to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras Santo Domingo Group

texts.es:
La formación del presente comité fue gracias a que una de las miembros oyó hablar del programa de mujeres emprendedoras, la idea le fue de mucho agrado y decidió organizar a sus vecinas y amigas de la ciudad de Carapeguá. Todas ellas se unieron con el propósito de obtener mayores ingresos económicos y de esa forma ayudar a sus familias. Actualmente está formado por 10 mujeres, todas ellas trabajan de forma conjunta y solidaria dentro de un ambiente de respeto.
La Señora Marta es tejedora, ella se dedica a esto hace ya mucho tiempo, pues desde pequeña aprendió esta profesión. Por medio de este trabajo ella ha podido mantenerse y mantener a su familia. Ella está muy orgullosa con el trabajo que hace, pues es un trabajo digno y honesto. Comenta que todo lo que hace es por el bien de su familia y de todos quienes dependen de ella. Se define como una mujer trabajador a y luchadora sin temor al trabajo.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de hilos, kits de agujas, telas y demás para la elaboración de los tejidos que realiza. Desde ya agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que esta le da.
texts.en:
The formation of this communal bank occurred thanks to one of the members, who heard people talking about a program for entrepreneurial women and liked the idea very much. She decided to organize her friends and neighbors in the city of Carapeguá.

Currently, the group consists of 10 women. All of them work together to achieve better incomes to take home, so that they can contribute to the expenses that arise day by day. 

Marta is a weaver. She has done this work for a long time, learning the profession when she was very young. Through this work, she has been able to support herself and her family. She is very proud of the work she does, since it is honest and dignified work. She comments that everything she does is for the good of her family and for all those who depend on her. 

She is requesting the loan to buy thread, needle kits, fabric and other supplies to make her weavings.

loans.use: compra de hilos, agujas, telas y demás para la confección de los tejidos.

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en:
The mileage that comes with hard work is invariably success. When a go-getter blazes a trail, exactly what 32-year-old Ambrose did when he set forth in his business journey a decade ago, he has success in his stride. This success is, however, dependent on other variables. To wit: the kind of business you are involved in, how you relate to your clients and how you constantly restock. All these can play to your strengths as long as you remain focused.

Ambrose plies a farming and banana sales business in Ibanda. The fact that he sells most of his bananas in one of Ibanda's biggest food markets has made his business pick up lots of steam from the point of view of profits. A decade's long track record in this business has strengthened his resolve to succeed even more. On the side, he has a timber sales enterprise that he ekes out side income from. Monthly this business generates him close to 300,000 Ugandan shillings as income. He anticipates more profits in the aftermath of using this Kiva loan. Ambrose intends to utilize this Kiva loan to purchase another piece of land to expand his banana farm.

loans.use: to purchase another piece of land to expand his banana farm.

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Ma.Elena is married and has two children. She sells groceries such as sugar, rice, oil and noodles. Her small store is located in her house. She has been working in this business for two years. Ma. Elena chose this type of work to help her husband and to have more income for the household. 

A challenge that Ma. Elena faces is her youngest daughter’s health. At this time it is too cold. She faces this challenge by being very careful with her daughter’s health as well as being careful with the rest of the family's health.

She will use the loan to buy merchandise for her store. Ma. Elena’s dream is to see her business grow until it becomes a large grocery store.

She is a very enterprising person. Together with her husband, she is very optimistic about getting her children ahead. She is very grateful for the opportunity to grow and to reach her dreams.

loans.use: to buy drinks, spices, milk, candies and snack foods for her store

loans.name: María Gabriela

texts.es:
María Gabriela integrante del Banco comunal “Amaican” perteneciente a la comuna de Pudahuel, ciudad de Santiago. 
Ella se dedica al servicio de disfraces y los arrienda por día en su casa. Entrega este servicio desde hace 5 años. Cuenta con 700 disfraces para niños y adultos. Estos los compra en el barrio “Patronato”, también por fardos en distribuidoras y además los confecciona ella. 
María Gabriela tiene publicidad de su negocio por internet, lo que ha facilitado que el número de clientes se incremente. 
Con el crédito comprará disfraces típicos, específicamente de huaso, chilote, pascuense, entre otros. 
Sus metas son seguir adquiriendo más variedad de disfraces, para contar con un mejor servicio para sus clientes.
María Gabriela vive junto a sus padres y 3 hermanos, quienes también le ayudan atender su negocio, cuando ella no se encuentra en su domicilio. 
Sus sueños son terminar su carrera universitaria en la carrera de laboratista dental. Sus motivaciones de continuar con el negocio se deben principalmente a que con estos ingresos puede costear sus estudios superiores y la disponibilidad horaria que le brinda tiempo para estudiar.
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida del crédito otorgado por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio y la posibilidad de generar mayores ganancias. María Gabriela se siente muy cómoda con el grupo del Banco comunal, ya que las relaciones interpersonales son muy buenas y es un grupo muy afiatado. Las capacitaciones han sido muy buenas y le han servido para organizar su negocio.
Pudahuel es una comuna del sector poniente de Santiago (capital de Chile), región Metropolitana. Es un vocablo del mapudungun (lengua mapuche) que se traduce como “lugar donde se juntan las aguas” o “lugar de charcos”, debido a que posee una variada red fluvial compuesta por el río Mapocho y los esteros Lampa, Carén y Las Cruces, lo que favorece sus suelos para la producción agrícola por la existencia de abundante agua subterránea.
texts.en:
María Gabriela is a member of the “Amaican” Communal Bank in the commune of Pudahuel, city of Santiago.

She operates a costume business from her home and charges a per day rental fee. She has been providing this service for five years.  She has 700 costumes for children and adults.  She buys them in the barrio of Patronato and by bundle from distributors.  She also makes costumes.

María Gabriela has marketed her business on the internet, which has made it possible to increase her customer base.  With the loan, she will buy typical costumes, specifically Huasco, Chilate (the native people of Chiloé Island), Pascuense (the native people of Easter Island) and others.  Her goals are to continue acquiring a wide variety of costumes in order to provide better service to her customers.

María Gabriela lives with her parents and three brothers who also help her take care of her business when she is not home.  Her dream is to complete her university degree in dental laboratory technology.  She continues with her business mainly because the income pays for her college studies and the flexibility of the schedule gives her time to study.

She is very happy and grateful for the loan provided by Fondo Esperanza, since it will allow her to invest in her business and possibly generate more profits.  Maria Gabriela feels very comfortable with the communal bank as interpersonal relationships are very good and the group works very well together.  The training had been very good and has helped her organize her business.

Pudahuel is a commune in the western sector of Santiago (capital of Chile), Metropolitan region.  It is a Mapudungun word (of the Mapuche language) that translates as “place where the waters meet” or “place of puddles” because it has a diverse network of rivers comprised of the Mapocho River and the Lampa, Carén, and Las Cruces estuaries.  Their soils are favored for agricultural production because of the existence of abundant groundwater.

loans.use: to buy tyical costumes, specifically Huaso, Chilote, Pasuense, and others.

loans.name: Luz Elena

texts.es:
La señora Luz Elena tiene la edad de 26 años, estudio hasta la primaria y se encuentra casada con el señor Alberto el cual tiene la ocupacion de albañil, ellos tiene 2 hijos uno estudia la primaria y el otro el preescolar en su comunidad, ellos vivien en una zona que se caracteriza por que ah se se siembre cañan y se produce azucar.

Ella nos comenta que desde hace un año se dedica a la venta de ropa para poder apoyar a sus esposo con los gastos del hogar.

Doña Luz Elena realiza sus ventas casa por casa, ofrece sus productos y en ocaciones ya con sus clientes levanta pedido y ella trae los productos que le pidieron aunque en estos momentos vende mas ropa de dama y caballeros pues sus amigos y vecinos les  piden mas, es asi que obtiene mas ganancias por sus ventas.

Ella necesita este credito para la compra de ropa interior de dama y caballero, blusas, pantalones, shorts, calcetines, camisas, playeras y herramientas para la albañileria para posteriormente venderlos.

Doña Luz Elena espera que con este credito sus ganancias aumenten y su negocio cresca cada dia mas y asi tener una mejor calida de vida para ella y su familia
texts.en:
Luz Elena is 26 and studied until primary school. She is married to Alberto, who is a bricklayer, and they have 2 sons, one in primary school and the other in pre-school in their community. They live in an area characterized by its sugar and sugar cane production.

Luz Elena tells us that she has been selling clothing for one year in order to help her husband with household expenses. She makes her sales door to door, presenting her wares and occasionally taking orders from clients and then bringing them the items they
order. On those occasions, when she takes orders, she sells more women's and men’s clothing, since her friends and neighbors more often place orders and it is in this way that she makes more profits from her sales.

She needs this loan to buy women’s and men’s underwear, blouses, pants, shorts, socks, shirts, T-shirts, as well as bricklayer’s tools, to later sell them. Luz Elena hopes that with this loan her profits will increase and her business will grow more every day, thereby providing a better quality of life for herself and her family.

loans.use: to sell clothing.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has five children.
 
Rebecca has a retail shop that sells vegetables like onions and garlic. She has had this business for one year. 

She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Rebecca is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Rebecca hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Dukorerehamwe/msny Group

texts.fr:
Eugène  fait partie du groupe Dukorerehamwe. Le nom du groupe signifie « travaillons ensemble ». Il a 42 ans et il est marié avec 3 enfants de 3 à 8 ans, dont 3 scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est  3 ans de secondaire.

Eugène est cultivateur de riz. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de faire la semence sélectionnée du riz et utilisation des fertilisants. Dans les prochaines années, Eugène voudrait être parmi les meilleurs cultivateurs de riz dans sa région et acheter d’autres surfaces de riz. Avec les profits, il prévoit d’éduquer et soigne ses enfants.
texts.en:
Eugène is a member of the Dukorerehamwe group.  The group's name means 'Let's Work Together'.  Eugène is 42 years old, married, and has three children who are between 3 and 8 years old.  All three are in school.  Eugène completed three years of his secondary education.

Eugène is a rice farmer and this is his first loan cycle with ACB.  He will use his loan to buy chemical fertilizers for his rice crop.

Eugène's strategy for growing his business is to sow selected rice seed and use fertilizers.  In the coming years, he would like to become one of the best rice growers in his region and buy more land for growing rice.  He plans to use the profits he makes to educate and take care of his children.

loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizers for his rice crop

loans.name: Fortunes Group

texts.en:
Thandiwe is a 35-year-old widow who lives in Shurugwi with her two children and one dependant who is attending a university. She has a hairdressing salon and a flee market stall which she has operated since 2006. She has 3 employees paid on a commission basis.

Her business is seasonal. It does well during the November-December holidays but experiences lower sales thereafter.
She is requesting a loan of $400 to buy Dark and Lovely (a brand name) hair-straightening kits for her salon and clothes to increase her flee market stock. If the business does well, she intends to finish building her house in Shurugwi and also send her children to better schools.

loans.use: To buy hair-straightening kits for her salon and clothes for sale at the flee market

loans.name: Dorris

texts.en: Dorris is 32 years old and lives in West Point. She is single and has a 12-year-old child that is presently in school and lives at home. For the past 8 years, Dorris has been selling fashion clothes in her shop. She has a lot of customers and her daily sales are very high during the dry season. She is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for her business. She plans to expand her business and wishes her child to have a brighter future.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for her business

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina, age 31, has a grocery store business in Yei, South Sudan. She has operated her business for four years. Her husband has his own business and they have no children.
 
Selina has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan in order to purchase sorghum, maize, and beans to offer for sale. She plans to save the extra income from this loan to build a house in future.

loans.use: to purchase sorghum, maize, and beans for sale.

loans.name: Cristo Y Nuestro Esfuerzo 4 & 7 Group

texts.en:
Marie is the coordinator of her group, Cristo Y Nuestro Esfuerzo 4 & 7 (Christ and Our Effort). She is a young woman who is just 26 years old. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her parents. She says that her most difficult challenge is to recover her profits after she sells on credit. In the meantime, she plans to continue working and studying. 

Marie is excited to be taking out a third loan with Esperanza. She has had her business for two years, starting out with her own savings. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying some bags of used clothes and different miscellaneous products, like shoes, cosmetics and others. She is planning to use her business profits to become a professional and to help her family.

Marie´s group is located in the rural area surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. She thanks all of you for your support!!!

loans.use: to buy bags of used clothing and miscellaneous products

loans.name: Maisa

texts.en:
Maisa is a 38 year-old woman from Irbid, Jordan and a mother of four children.

Maisa decorates flowers and then sells them. She operates from home and she is requesting a loan of 500 JD to purchase materials needed for her business such as ribbons, glue...etc.

Maisa is looking to expand her bsuiness by increasing her sales volume.

loans.use: to purchase ribbons, glue, etc)

loans.name: Sabougnouma (La Bonne Cause) Group

texts.fr:
Sabougnouma est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala constitué de 1 célibataire et de 9 mariées qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 29 ans et sont mères d’au moins 3 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels le bois de chauffe, les habillements,  les céréales, les fruits et légumes etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 1 an. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et  le prêt précédent  a été bien remboursé. 
Mamou Issa est un membre du groupe Sabougnouma qui vend du bois de chauffe.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe auprès des producteurs. Elle se procure  en bois de chauffe dans les différents coins de brousse : Kapala,  Try et Beresso. Son stock de bois entreposé dans un endroit de la concession, est très important. Elle vend le bois en détail et au comptant à la maison, à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 70 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mamou Issa compte réaliser 80 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elle souhaite renforcer son partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks  soient plus permanents. 
NB / Fatoumata est absente sur cette photo de groupe pour raison du décès de son enfant.
texts.en:
Sabougnouma Group is made up of one unmarried and nine married women, who live in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. They average 29 years of age and at least three children.

The women of the group sell various products, such as firewood, clothes, cereals, fruits and vegetables, etc. In order to bolster their businesses, last year they decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso.

They are seeking their second group loan, and the previous one was repaid without problems.

Mamou Issa is a member of the group, and she sells firewood. She intends to use her loan to buy cartloads of firewood from producers. She gets her firewood supplies in various parts of the bush: Kapala, Try, and Beresso.

She has a very large stock, stored somewhere in her concession. She retails the firewood for cash at her home, to a very diverse clientele.

Whereas the members of the group intend to turn an average profit of XOF 70'000 (ca US$ 130) during this loan cycle, Mamou Issa intends to reach XOF 80'000 (ca US$ 150).

In addition to repaying the loan, the women will use part of the income to cope with the family's daily expenses.

Mamou Issa would like to strengthen her partnership with Soro Yiriwaso, in order to have more permanent stocks.

Note: Fatoumata is missing in the group photograph because of the death of her child.

loans.use: to buy cartloads of firewood

loans.name: Art

texts.en: Art, 51, resides in Prey Veng Province. She and her husband are farmers. When possible, her husband also operates a mechanical plow that is available for rental to farmers in his village. Art is requesting a loan of $1100 to purchase a rice threshing machine for personal use and for rental to villagers. By doing so, her family will be able to generate more income. In the future, Art would like to use any additional income to purchase a truck to transport and sell rice. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a rice threshing machine for personal use and rental.

loans.name: Estevana Del Socorro

texts.es: Estebaba  de 50 años se dedica a la venta de productos fritos y jugos naturales elaborados con frutas tropicales de la región, como guayaba, aguacate, piña, mango, tamarindo, guanábana etc; Su idea de negocio surgió cuando trabajando con una señora que vendía congelados y fritos en un hotel del centro histórico, decidió hacer lo mismo de manera independiente, así fue como empezó con un capital de trabajo pequeño y poco a poco ha ido creciendo. Diariamente su competencia  es mayor y sus costos son superiores a los de la competencia que maneja mejores precios que ella; la razón es que compra por pequeñas cantidades, casi a diario y sus gastos de transporte son superiores,  además de que en sus compras no gana descuentos por las pequeñas cantidades en las cuales obtiene sus productos, porque su capital de trabajo es insuficiente para lograr volúmenes de compra. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el que comprara en mayor cantidad insumos alimenticios, que le permitan competir con buenos precios y un mejor margen de ganancias. Así mismo como tiene  como sus nuevos clientes a las tiendas del sector, podrá responderle a sus pedidos oportunamente, tal como ella lo ha planeado con su credikiva, con el cual tambien le alcanzará para comprar una vitrina y hacer una mejor exhibición de sus fritos.
texts.en:
Estevana, 50, works selling fried products and natural juices made with regional tropical fruits such as guava, avocado, pineapple, mango, tamarind, soursop, etc.  The idea for her business came up when she was working with a woman who was selling frozen and fried snacks in a hotel in the historic district.  She decided to do the same on her own, so she began with a small amount of working capital and little by little it has grown.

Her competition grows every day and her expenses are more than those of the competition, which has better prices.  This is because she buys almost daily in smaller quantities, and her transportation expenses are higher.  Also, she does not earn discounts for her purchases because of the small quantities in which she gets her products, since her working capital is insufficient to get volume sales.

This is the reason she is coming for a Kiva loan, the first loan request she has made to Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  With it she will buy food supplies wholesale, which will allow her to compete with good prices and a better profit margin.  Likewise, as she has new customers in the area stores, she will be able to respond to their requests opportunely, just as she has planned it with her Kiva loan, with which she also will buy a display case to make a better display of her fried snacks.

loans.use: to buy food supplies wholesale and a display case.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is a 45-year-old married woman with two children aged 16 and 7. Vilma's husband works as a farmer.

Vilma is also a farmer working in Trinidad, Bohol. She has been growing and selling rice for twelve years. Vilma works hard to support her family and send her children to school. She requested this loan to purchase fertilizers and certified seeds. Vilma hopes to achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and certified seeds.
